description: The elimination of damaged cell components is essential for the maintenance of the body's tissues and organs. An international research team has made significant findings on mechanisms for the clearing of cellular wastes, showing that strength training activates such mechanisms. The findings could form the basis for new therapies for heart failure and nerve diseases, and even afford benefits for manned space missions.
title: Strength training activates cellular waste disposal

description: A new study provides insights on the geophysics behind asteroid formation and evolution.
title: NASA's DART impact permanently changed the shape and orbit of asteroid moon

description: A collaborative investigation among experts in Alzheimer's disease and multiple sclerosis (MS) finds evidence that MS patients are less likely to have amyloid plaques, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease, than adults without MS.
title: Multiple sclerosis appears to protect against Alzheimer's disease

description: To guide future research into solar geoengineering, an international group of scientists is making specific recommendations for evaluating proposals in order to identify the most feasible and legitimate scenarios for stratospheric aerosol intervention.
title: Scientists propose guidelines for solar geoengineering research

description: A new study has used a series of innovative field experiments to show how plants combine circadian clock signals with environmental cues under naturally fluctuating conditions.
title: Innovative field experiments shed light on biological clocks in nature

description: A 3D quantum spin liquid has been discovered in the vicinity of a member of the langbeinite family. The material's specific crystalline structure and the resulting magnetic interactions induce an unusual behavior that can be traced back to an island of liquidity. An international team has made this discovery with experiments at the ISIS neutron source and theoretical modelling on a nickel-langbeinite sample.
title: Langbeinites show talents as 3D quantum spin liquids

description: The global concentrations of one of the main air pollutants known to affect human health have been graphically illustrated for the first time by a team of scientists.
title: New images reveal global air quality trends

description: Researchers argue that to protect human wellbeing global decisions with the potential to impact the environment must be guided by our understanding of the inseparable connection between humans and nature. The article's authors are aiming to support fair and inclusive decision-making for a healthy ocean for people and planet.
title: Scientists call for an update in environmental decision making that takes human rights into account

description: Chlamydiae are sexually transmitted pathogens that can apparently survive in the human gut for a long time.
title: Chlamydia can settle in the intestine

description: Superconductivity theory proposed by physics team validated in international experiment: Cooper pairs display wave-like distribution in Kagome metals, enabling new technological applications like superconducting diodes.
title: Kagome superconductor makes waves

description: A team of researchers has created a digital pathology platform based on artificial intelligence. The platform uses new algorithms developed by the team and enables fully automated analysis of tissue sections from lung cancer patients. The platform makes it possible to analyze digitized tissue samples on the computer for lung tumors more quickly and accurately than before.
title: Artificial intelligence improves lung cancer diagnosis

description: The income and education levels of a child's environment determine their relationship to nature, not whether they live in a city or the countryside. The results run counter to the assumption that growing up in the countryside automatically increases our connection to nature, and yet the study also shows that nature close to home increases children's well-being.
title: Socioeconomics shape children's connection to nature more than where they live

description: What makes someone seem wise? People view wisdom through the lens of applying knowledge and thinking logically as well as considering others' feelings and perceptions, according to researchers who looked at perceptions of wisdom across 12 countries and five continents.
title: People seen as wise share these characteristics

description: How effective medications are depends on various factors, including the time of day when they are administered. Why? Because our bodies don't always function exactly the same. Instead, they follow the cycle set by their internal clock, otherwise known as circadian rhythm. But since each person's circadian rhythm is different and depends on a number of different factors, it is difficult to tailor medication schedules to an individual patient's body clock. Researchers have now developed a method for determining the optimum time of cancer treatment based on certain breast cancer cell lines.
title: When is the best time of day for cancer treatment?

description: Dementia with Lewy bodies is a type of dementia that is similar to both Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease but studies on long-term treatments are lacking. A new study highlights the potential cognitive benefits of cholinesterase inhibitor treatment.
title: Alzheimer's drug may slow down cognitive decline in dementia with Lewy bodies

description: Building on a landmark algorithm, researchers propose a way to make a smaller and more noise-tolerant quantum factoring circuit for cryptography.
title: Toward a code-breaking quantum computer

description: Obesity-related cancer rates in China were rising at an alarming 3.6% every year between 2007 and 2021 while non-obesity-related cancers remained stable, according to the first comprehensive study. The increase is particularly pronounced among young people, highlighting the urgent need for better public health policies to address China's growing overweight and obesity rates.
title: Rates of obesity-related cancer are rising sharply in young Chinese people
